oblige.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if you are obliged to do something, you have to do it because the situation, the law, a duty etc makes it necessary
oblige.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Many parents feel obliged to pay for at least part of the wedding.
The minister was obliged to report at least once every six months.
Circumstances had obliged him to sell the business.
oblige.translation[0].definitions[0].not: Oblige is often passive in this meaning
oblige.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to do something that someone has asked you to do
oblige.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: It’s always a good idea to oblige important clients.
If you need a ride home, I’d be happy to oblige.
oblige.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to make it necessary for someone to do something
oblige.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: As a result of falling profits, we were obliged to close the factory.
oblige.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to do something that someone has asked you to do
oblige.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: If you want something that is not on the menu, the staff are happy to oblige.
They wanted more direct information than we were giving, and we’ve obliged them.
